_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Diamond Vogel - North Inc.
Minneapolis, MN

Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

The Risk Management Plan for Diamond Vogel - North Inc. covers a single 6,000-gallon bulk storage vessel used to handle Toluene diisocyanate. All current applicable ANSI and ASTM standards are strictly followed regarding the maintenance and operation of this facility.

Diamond Vogel - North Inc. is a producer of liquid architectural and industrial coatings. One of the processes utilized here is the incorporation of Toluene diisocyanate (TDI) as a pre-cursor resin for making certain coatings. The TDI is stored in a single 6,000-gallon vessel that is in an isolated room. The controls for the incorporation of the TDI into the mixing process are in a second separate room. All of the parts on the storage vessel and the incorporation process are approved for use with TDI.

The facility is only operated during normal business hours, operating only a single work shift. A hard-wired alarm system and a quick response security company protect the facility during all non-work hours.

Diamond Vogel - North Inc. has taken a number of steps to insure the integrity and safety of the process, and for accident prevention.
1. The Toluene diisocyanate storage and transfer systems adhere to all applicable ANSI, ASTM, NFPA, and OSHA requirements.
2. Annual training is required for all personnel handling, or transferring the TDI. The training includes properties of the product, safe handling procedures, first aid, and emergency response and process shutdown procedures.
3. Proper use and storage of personal protective equipment.
4. Use of good management processes, as specified by industry standards and training aids.
5. Periodic scheduled maintenance and safety inspections.
6. Proper qualifications of contractor personnel.
7. Maintenance of sensors and alarms, to warn of any system malfunction.

The Toluene diisocyanate storage vessel is kept in a sealed, limited access room. Changes are made in the syst

em when necessary or when required by regulation change. Periodic evaluations of the procedures help determine whether or not a change in operations should be made to provide increased safety to the operators and to the community.
